segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 So, I'm Paul Coggin. I'm from the U.S., specifically live in Huntsville, Alabama, down in the southeast
corner of the U.S. My, primarily my experience is network infrastructure, service provider,
telecommunications, utilities, both implementing, architecting, and securing the network critical
network infrastructure, and also the heavy emphasis on penetration testing. And today,
for the last three years, I'm specifically 100% focused on red teaming. But as I mentioned,
I got, I've been reading, like everyone, a lot about the SS7 protocols that are being
hacked and having a telecom background. My experience was always in the data side with
just a little bit of voice experience. I primarily just provided transport for the
voice services and worked more on the data and the cable TV side of the house or service
provider. And I started thinking, it's like, we were seeing all these publications about
SS7 protocol vulnerabilities, and I was like, well, how does someone actually get access
to export these SS7 vulnerabilities? Because those are typically closed networks and not
just openly, intentionally open to the internet. So here's some ideas if someone was going
to go after these networks, how would they get that initial handhold so that they could
exploit the protocol vulnerabilities that have been published by a number of organizations
here recently. So before we dive into that, let's do an overview of SS7. If you're like
me and you're not a class 5 switch operator, if you're not a voice carrier expert, let's
go and jump into a quick overview of SS7. So SS7 is basically, think of SS7 as BGP,
the border gateway protocol for the internet. Well, SS7 is the equivalent of BGP for the
PSTN, the public switch telephone network. It's how all the different voice networks
around the world communicate. And just like we have these open trust relationships with
BGP so that we all can communicate across the internet, send email, surf the web, et
cetera, well, SS7, between all the different telco service providers, there's a trust relationship
that everybody's doing what they're supposed to be doing and doing due diligence. And we
know with like all BGP in the news, not everybody's doing what they're supposed to be doing, right?
And SS7, especially to a lot of people like myself in InfoSec, it's kind of like a black
box. We just trust the voice guys to be doing whatever it is, their magic in making things
work. But SS7 has been around, it got created initially like in the 70s by AT&T. Whenever
you're making phone calls between your local exchange carriers, your central offices, say
your regional area, your cities, when a call leaves that local area, it is going to utilize
SS7 when you're using your cell phone network and roaming around. All those communications
are happening with SS7. SMS is using it, the call blocking, emergency services in the U.S.
we call it E911 for dialing emergency services. Caller ID, all those things depend on SS7
protocol. Now, when you start talking about the architecture of SS7, you start talking
to voice telecommunications people, you quickly start getting drowning in a whole new set
of acronyms. And a few of those acronyms are referring to the no types. You have what they
call signal transport point. And you can think of that signal transport point, the STP, think
of it as a router for the PSTN, for the SS7, basically it's like an SS7 router, the way
I would, being an old school router person, that's how I think about it. And it also has,
not only does it route SS7 messages, it also has some basic filter capabilities, just like
a router has access control list capabilities, some basic filtering, basic firewall capabilities.
The STP has some basic filtering capabilities as well built into it. And then you get into
what they call the service switching point, the SSP, and that is what they call a class
five switch, that is the switch that in the past it would fill up a room, it would be
just rows and rows of equipment that would fill up a room, maybe your Siemens, Nortel,
Lucent, just rows and rows of equipment. And now it's been consolidated down to a soft
switch where it might be just one 21 inch rack with a couple of sun boxes, a couple
of Unix boxes for redundancy. You can consolidate all that down now. And so it's a soft switch,
but it's basically providing what they call class five services, where you can run voice
services for a whole city, large geographic area. And that's providing the voice, the
fax, the modem capability, dial tone services. And then you get into what they call the service
control point, the SCP, and that is the database that has all the numbers for, say 800 numbers,
and the cellular has the mobile subscribers, the different calling card services, et cetera.
That's all going to be in the service control point, the SCP, which being a database, that's
going to be a target-rich environment to get a hold of. It's going to have some good
information in it from a security standpoint. So from an architecture standpoint, when we
talk about SS7, here's where we're talking, like I said, I'm an old school network person,
so I want to know how the network's built. Everything for me is about the network. So
here's what the SS7 network architecture looks like. You have your STPs that are in the network,
and they're going to be connected to your SCP and your SSPs. We talked about that service
control point and that service switch point. They're going to be connected with links.
There's a lot of specialized links in SS7, and it's going to connect to those services
with A-links, which are basically in Europe and most parts of the world. It's going to
be E1s. In the U.S., we use T1s. But, you know, when you're talking about SS7, it's
specific terminology for the functionality and features that are being provided over
those links. So A-links are going to tie in your SCPs and your SSPs back to the STPs.
Basically, like I said, they're providing SS7 routing functionality. And at the bottom,
you can see where you've got SSPs that may be tied together with F-links, and that architecture
may happen in a large city environment, maybe, say, in Warsaw, where you have a really large
city. In such a dense population, there might be multiple switches, and they're tied together
with SSPs or tied together with F-links. For congestion and for redundancy, you may have
what they call E-links or AA-links, which are redundant A-links, so that the A-links
have redundancy for messaging, if needed. And then in the center there, we show C-links,
where you may have STPs that are clustered together. And if you have STPs, nodes that
are clustered together, you would use C-links to tie those together. And then those B-links
that we see, those B-links are used to tie, like I mentioned with the BGP, where you have
the peering on the global internet, those peering points with those B-links are used
to tie in different telco networks in the SS7. That's how they integrate together is
with B-links. Then a real quick overview of cellular network architecture. Over on
the left, we have the base transceiver stations, which is going to be your towers, where our
mobile phones, our mobile devices are jumping on different RF channels, and as we roam around,
we get on different base transceiver stations. And those base transceiver stations are controlled
by the base station controllers that are managing and keeping up with us as we roam
across different towers and different networks and report back up to the mobile switching
center. And all of that infrastructure is managed by the operation support subsystem.
And think of that operation support subsystem, the OSS, as the NOC, the network operation
center for all of this. That's where the management, the monitoring, the health and status, configuration
control is the brains of that operation. And it would also, that OSS would also connect
into the business systems of the telco enterprise network. And that's a very target-rich environment
from my experience. When you say that OSS, think lots of systems, lots of databases,
lots of apps, lots of remote access from vendors where they can get in and help, you know,
keep the services working. And also where customers, there's going to be trust relationships
over to the right where customers may be interacting and automatically provisioning
services from home, possibly to a soft switch web interface. That kind of integration could
be happening in there. So there's interesting trust relationships to be audited there and
evaluated. And then you get down here in the mobile switching center. And down in the mobile
switching center, that's where the real brains of the operation is for the, for your cellular
network. And this is where you got your home location register. That service, that system
is keeping up with the cell phones that are a part of that cellular network. And then
you got the authentication center that is associated with the HLR. And that's where
your SIM cards are being authenticated to verify that your phone is good. And that's
going to, so that's going to authenticate your SIMs. And then you got the visit, visitor
location register. And that is, and that system is keeping up with users that are roaming
around the network. When you leave your network and you're on different parts, so you say
like I'm in the US and I'm over here in Europe, I'm reporting back to the VLR, the visitor
location registrar, that I'm not on my home network. I'm not back at the HLR. I'm over
here on connected, I'm roaming. So that VLR will keep up with that. And then you got your
equipment identity register. And what that's doing is it's going to keep up with stolen
phones, phones that may be rogue, that may be lost, etc. And then again you're getting,
all of this is going to be integrated and tied in with other telcos based on that architecture
we showed previously with all the, with the PSTN. I'm an old school, like I said I'm an
old school network person and to me I'm all about the PCAP. I want to see, we can talk
all these protocols and acronyms, but I want to see the network, I want to see a PCAP.
I want to see what does a packet capture look like. So here's what a packet capture or really
a frame capture I guess you would say, because this is, there's no way as you'll see in here,
there's no IP. We're looking at a frame and then we drop down into SS7 messages and down
here I got circled here, you can see where, right here you got ISDN, it's encapsulated
in these message transfer part level frames here. And then you can see where we're got
a calling number and a called number and the calling number here. So there's no IP. This
is all pure dialing and over ISDN here. And this kind of capture would not be happening
over Ethernet. You would have to have a specialized test set. Typically in the U.S. what I'm familiar
with is a test set called a T-Bird that will go in and capture frames off of like a E1,
E3, T1, T3, where you can capture those frames at that level. And then you can take it and
you can import it into a tool like Wireshark or whatever your favorite protocol analyzer
is. But I wanted you to see this for reference. Now here's where things are interesting, because
we're all a bunch of InfoSec folks. We want it all on IP where we can ping it and we can
target it and we can point Metasploit at it, right? Go hack the world. So here's an
example of where you can see you've got your frame and you've got your Ethernet and we
have IP and then the SS7 is encapsulated in IP. So the world of today and tomorrow, this
SS7 network that used to be just a closed, non-IP, not pingable from the world has been
brought online. And now we can ping it and we can route to it. And so we can go and put
in backdoors. We can get access and drop in whatever our favorite tool is for backdooring
the network, whether it's a Pineapple or some kind of 3G, 4G, 5G backdoor device on that
network and be able to, from our laptop, anywhere in the world, be able to integrate in with
this SS7 network and influence communications, because it's all in IP.
So here's where I want to focus and get you to think about is here's an example of what
a telecommunications network might look like. I spent 15 years building service providers,
telcos, utilities, where the services were all converging together. It was getting hard
to tell the difference between a cable company, a phone company, and a utility, except for
the utilities provided services like gas, water, and power. That was their differentiator.
But they were all going and getting into offering cable TV, voice, and Internet services, and
Metro Ethernet, et cetera, services to their customers. But they all have a lot of common
services. So what you have is you've got the video head in, you've got their voice switch,
their soft switch, which is basically a lot of times might be redundant Solaris boxes,
and whatever vendor app they choose for their class 5 switch. And you've got different services
for monitoring, for billing integration, the middleware. And then of course you've got
your services like Lawful Intercept, where Lawful Intercept, we talked about yesterday
in my workshop, Lawful Intercept is where the government can come in and provide a warrant,
provide paperwork to telco service providers and say we want all the traffic for this individual.
And so when that is provided, then the telecommunications infrastructure provider will enable capability
so that A and B start talking, a perfect copy is sent to C, and A and B have no idea that
a perfect copy of all their communications is being sent to C. That's Lawful Intercept.
And that's used around the world. And you'll see that in all the different vendor infrastructure,
both network and voice and other specialized telecommunications will have that capability
in the network. And then you go and ease down into the network, and you get down into
their core infrastructure, and that's where you're going to have your MPLS core network,
what I call BFRs, big freaking routers, you know, routers as big as a door. They're basically
you know, Blair 3 switches with lots of ports, lots of speeds and feeds, and they're also
going to have your optical network, your DWDM, your SONET in the US, SDH in Europe, other
parts of the world. All of that magic is going to be happening here at the core. And
then you're going to drop down into the access layer, depending on the provider, the business
model. They may be offering active Ethernet, which is basically Ethernet out to the business
or the customer home or passive optical as an architecture. Maybe, you know, they're
still offering T1, E1, and DSL services in some parts of the world. But the key thing
that I want you to get out of this that I've seen, when you're out there buying services
and you're negotiating for your large critical infrastructure organizations, you've got to
dig in and ask the hard questions. Because here's the thing that people don't know and
they don't want anybody to ask the hard questions about. Majority of these services and solutions
are back door to high heaven. I have read the contracts. I've been in the rooms when
they've been negotiated with providers. And I'm going to show you some examples where
they will have remote access. They'll have SSH access. They will have SSL access, some
kind of VPN where they drop in their own routers, they drop in their own firewalls, and totally
bypass the infrastructure for, say, the Internet guys, the people who are included in IP.
They understand security risk and they understand how to go and lock things down. But you get
in, like every organization, you get into politics. You get into revenue streams and
business plans. And you have the voice. You have the video. And everybody's got their
own empire. They have their own political influence. And their vendors have a lot of
power and authority. And they'll come in and totally bypass, in some cases, the security
that the Internet, the people that are fluent in the Internet would like to have in place.
I've seen them just totally bypass that. And I'm going to go into some examples.
So what I call this is the, everybody talks about the APT. I call this the VPT, the vendor
persistent threat. I usually get last with that. So I call it the VPT, the vendor persistent
threat, because the vendors are putting in these back doors into these networks where
they can get this remote access. And this is where we're going to dive into how they
may be, people can get into the SS7 network. Now, one strategy, before, if you're a consulting
company or you're involved with auditing critical infrastructure, maybe you work for a big consulting
company or you have associations with government agencies and you're out doing auditing and
evaluating the security of critical infrastructure, or maybe you work for a critical infrastructure
vendor, and you're looking at these things, here's how I like to look at networks. I like
to go and do all my recon, get all my intel, find out all the open source information.
Because one thing that you'll learn about in the telecom industry is everybody really
brags a lot about what they bought and purchased and likes to get their name put out there
in press releases that they implemented, XYZs, routers, XYZs, you know, soft switches or
cable TV head in, and they put all that information out there. And then it makes it real easy
to go and figure out what vendors you need to go find out who the field engineers are
that may be working on site and have a laptop with everybody's infrastructure information,
with everybody's static passwords and username, you know, username, passwords, so you know
who to go after. If you're a hacker, unauthorized hacker, a black hat, you would know who to
go target so you could pick it back off their laptop to go in and export the trust relationships
to get in these networks. So you're going to look at that network management, you know,
the billing system, the middleware that's tying the billing system to the provisioning
for the network. You can go and figure out, reverse engineer how the vendors do remote
access because one thing they are, they're consistent around the world. If you can get
in the head of a vendor and field engineers of how they access these networks, you can
go and get into all of them across the world because they're consistent. If they do SSH
in Europe, they're doing SSH probably in US. And when I say SSH, I'm talking about wide
open brute force it until you get in SSH access. Totally wide open, no account lock
out, real simple to guess passwords. And so you figure out those trust relationships between
those vendors and then develop yourself an attack tree and then you can, most likely
you're going to find a way into the network. You're going to find some vulnerabilities
and some access into the network if you do a good job here. So here's a real world example.
I like to do, I like to go into and use real world examples minus the guilty to protect
myself and, you know, protect them obviously. But most importantly to protect me.
This is some real world stories here. I've seen this numerous times. What'll happen is
we have in the middle of the network here, we have a transport network and this is the
speeds and feeds, the backbone of a utility, telco, service provider. This is, you know,
the optical network, the TDM, the telecommunications, the, you know, infrastructure
where they're provisioning E1s, T1s, E3s, T3s, all of that is, you know, gigabit ethernet,
all of that is being provisioned across this transport network here. And across those
services they may have, you know, their voice network here, you know, their SS7, their soft
switch services, their cable TV, all of that infrastructure is, all those services are going
to run across this. And what I've seen for both the transport network and for these voice networks,
I've seen this in multiple cases around the world, is where the vendors dropped in Linux boxes,
multi-honed, one leg into the network management portion of these networks,
the secure, you know, air gap. How many times, you know, that's one of the most abused terms in
infos, you know, networking and infosec and IT in general is air gap. So these air gap network
management networks, and what they do is they'll drop in a Linux box, one leg into the management
for, say, the voice network or for this transport network,
and then they'll have another leg, the second ethernet connection that totally bypasses the
security that the IT folks put in, that maybe the internet service provider folks put in,
who really understand how IP technologies work, you know, they understand STORT, and they
understand how to, you know, configure a Juniper, Cisco firewall, what have you. These voice guys
don't, and these vendors will go in and drop these boxes in with an open SSH service so that when
they're out on the road, what have you, and the customer has a problem, the field engineer can go
and come back in and help and support them. And what happens, as I've discovered, is they drop
these Linux boxes in, multi-honed, wired them to the world, and they're getting hacked to high
heaven, and their IDS is typically a bank somewhere in the world calling and telling them that their
network's got popped and is being used to attack their bank, you know, please cease and desist,
and it just amazes me, in many of these cases, the people who have hacked these networks don't
realize what they've gotten access to, because what they've done is they've gotten access to
what they call the EMS, the element management system, and think of element management system
as the network management system like SolarWinds, HP OpenView, the equivalent for these specialized
equipment, it might be the voice switch, it might be the optical gear, it might be the TDM gear, the sonic
gear, or the router vendor that's providing the MPLS transport services, and when you get
into a specialized vendor, they call it an EMS, an element management, and at EMS, they'll literally
drop that box in with multi-homed, and my head just wants to explode when I get, because I'll get the
call somewhere, you know, hey, you know, we've been hacked, we're getting letters and calls to stop
hacking, you know, and you go and dig in, oh my goodness, who did this, you know, but you
literally spend, you know, a half million dollars on security infrastructure, and you just totally
bypassed it with a patch cable, it's like, you know, you know, you just can't fix some things,
you can't fix politics, right, so here's another example,
pretty detailed example of a telco, which you have, of how a telco might get hacked,
and someone get access into this, into the SS7 network, similar to what we just showed,
the whole point is, how can we get access into that SS7 network, how does it go down real world,
well here's a more detailed diagram, and all these slides are being provided to the conference,
so you can go and study them offline, so you have a network operation,
where the brains of the operation is, all the blinky lights are being monitored and managed,
you got all the vendors, network management systems,
monitoring and provisioning, automated, you know, doing health and status of the network,
bringing new user services online, and all that brains and intel is happening here,
and it's integrated over to the OSS, as we showed on one of the first slides,
which is also going to be tied into, have the trust relationships,
over to the enterprise, where there's business systems and accounting,
built in, you know, the billing information, maybe user provisioning, so that the customer,
in customers can automatically provision new services, there's going to be trust relationships
into there, that opens up a whole other set of opportunities, if that hasn't been secured,
and again, they got the VPT over there, the vendors that want that remote access into all
that infrastructure, and so it comes down, and you have those trust relationships into your core
infrastructure, as we just discussed, and you got your voice services, you got your data services,
and your GSM, 3G, 4G, 5G services, that are going to be relying on these transport networks,
but what I want to call you out to, is maybe they're doing MPLS, maybe it's got,
they got some legacy frame relay still out there, what have you, but I had a personal experience,
where a customer, they built, they had a very large wide area network, a huge network,
like 60 something sites, and they went from one carrier, migrated from one carrier to a second
carrier, and as we were transit, we had to transition from the first carrier to the second
carrier, we had to buy all new brand new infrastructure, to get during this migration,
this transition, so the first carrier, every time we would go and cut a site over from the
first telco to the second telco, dropping in new router equipment, it turned out that the
first telco vendor, the incumbent, that was being migrated off of, they just abandoned all their
equipment in place, and so we ended up, they ended the customer, cut over all their sites,
and then through mergers and acquisitions, over doubled in size, the customer's like, hey,
the first telco abandoned all this equipment, we're not going to buy all new routers,
because all we're using is 64k and 128k connections for IBM green screens, you know,
back to mainframe type stuff, we don't, we don't need high speed routers, we're just going to use
this old stuff, they started doing recovery on these routers, and discover like, all of the
brains of the operations, because they just threw it away, somebody made a decision in a spreadsheet
that it wasn't good economics to go and pull all that equipment back, well what did they leave,
they left routers out there in place with all the passwords, all the routing policies, all the SNMP
community strings, how the trust relationships with the network operations center, they're, you
know, the information on the boxes that are collecting net flow, the syslog servers, all of
that intel just sat and left out there, I'm like, oh my god, you know, just left all that out there,
and that's, you know, and that's, and you can only imagine all that same equipment around the world
is showing up on like eBay and being sold, you know, refurb, and people are getting access to
this stuff, so that's, that's a, that's another example of how people can find their ways into
the telco, because this stuff is just getting out there, pushed a lot, some project managers
abandoning all this equipment with all of that intel and not bringing it back and having it
destroyed properly, and so, so you get that access, you get all this intel, you know now you can
revert based on what you've got from a remote site where the telco service provider is providing
managed services, you know, how much, you know, the cloud, you know, it's going to be secure because
it's the cloud, right, so they got a cloud-based service, and they got, but then still they got,
they got equipment out there at the customer prim, and it's got all this information with all this
juicy information with trust relationships, so now you can reverse engineer how this may, this
cloud up here may work, the NOC may actually work, and then all you have to do is go over to LinkedIn
and find out who your good targets are and figure out how you're going to pop them and piggyback in
if you don't even go, you know, direct through their internet connection, maybe through phishing
an email directly into the company, you know, me, if I was, if I was a black hat, I'd probably just go
after the user and try to figure out who their family members are and target their spouse on
Facebook or Instagram, you know, go through some social media service and find a way to piggyback
on their network connection back in to the network, just one thought, but anyway, this is a,
this is a one strategy that could get someone into a telco network possibly.
Now, so we, so we've got into the telco, we've got, we've covered a couple ways that someone
might break into the telco, what are they going to do, what, how are things going to go down once
they've gotten access into that voice SS7 network and they've got that initial handhold here,
well, if they're wanting to go and target the mobile phone subscribers,
one of the things they're going to need is they're going to need to get the
MC code for that subscriber, and the MC code for the phone is a unique identifier that all
the phones have that uniquely identify you on the cell phone network, so one of the things they're
going to need to do is they might have your phone number, they may know the STP point code,
they've figured that out through their intel, but they need that MC code for that phone,
and so what you can do is if they have this access, they can craft messages and impersonate
a SMS center and send a message up to the home location registrar for that phone number that
they want to target, and then that home location registrar would respond back, it would go and say
query the visitor location register information, and it would figure out where everything is at,
where the phone, where the user is at, and it would return back to the attacker
all of the information they requested, not only now is he going to have the phone number,
he's going to have the MC code, he's going to know, he's going to know the visitor location
register so that he can go and figure out where he's roaming at, et cetera, and now we can start
targeting this mobile user. There's one feature in SS7 that is being locked down, the trend,
based on my research, the trend is this feature is being locked down and taken away from
the attack surface, but it's still out there in some parts of the world, like every feature,
nothing is 100% locked down, it's like when everybody's shutting down XP, but there's some
people that are still running XP. Same thing with this anytime interrogation feature in SS7,
and what could happen is that the attacker that has gotten access to this SS7 network
can go and send a query into the home location registrar and export the anytime
interrogation feature, send up a crafted packet to the home location registrar,
and then it will go and query the visitor location registrar and find out where that
mobile user is, where that mobile phone, that mobile access device is somewhere in the world,
and when it finds out what visitor location registrar that is located on what it's using,
like say if they were targeting me, they would go and hit my HLR, my home location registrar
back in the U.S., and then find the VLR that I reported to, and they would go and hit the
local tower that I'm on, and then it would report back to the attacker, hey,
he's over in Gdynia this week, and then it would bring that information back.
But this anytime interrogation, like I said, that attack surface is slowly going away,
according to the research I've done, they're getting, shutting that down, but there's still,
there's always other vulnerabilities, right? You close one door and there's always others
that are open and just waiting to be discovered that haven't been locked down yet. So similarly,
we've still got our access here by whatever means, whatever attack path we've come up with,
and we start crafting packets, we can still, we can impersonate a home location registrar,
say somebody wants to target me, say someone, say in Asia wants to target me,
they could impersonate my home location registrar and send in a request and find out that,
and send it into the SS7 network, and find out that I'm over here in Poland,
and find out the visitor location registrar I'm on, because my home location registrar will
report it back. They'll send that, they're going to hit this VLR, and it'll go out here and query,
and find the tower that I'm on, and find the geographic region that I'm reporting back to,
and send that back to the attacker that is basically impersonating another MSC somewhere
in the world. And then they would know where I'm located at. They could find me, if that was their
goal. Now, what really, what really got me interested, what I started wanting to do this
project for, and do this research, and understand this better, was being able to do man-in-the-mill
attacks. And so here's how, and this is, so this is, just like we can, you know, we could do
man-in-the-mill attacks off of local ethernet, we can do man-in-the-mill attacks, say with like,
you know, and I talk about a lot in my previous talks, about being able to do man-in-the-mill
talks, both at the local level, with routing protocols inside of enterprise, or with BGP on
the global internet. Well, we can do the same thing with SS7, we can do a man-in-the-mill attack.
So we've gotten access into the PSTN here, onto the SS7, through some telcos SS7 access,
that we've exploited. We can, we can go, and we can, we can impersonate a mobile switching center.
We can, we can impersonate a, the cellular network here, and send up queries, well actually not
query, but an update to the home location registrar, and tell the home location registrar, hey,
